titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bernard Wolfe Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:19

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection includes correspondence, writings and research material, photographs, printed material, and personal papers relating to American author Bernard Wolfe. There is correspondence, including incoming and outgoing letters, with family, friends, writers, publishers, editors, and labor organizations. Individual corrrespondents include: Pearl Buck, Marcel Duhamel, Dwight MacDonald, Henry Miller, A. J. Muste, John Crowe Ranson, Harry Ross, and Wolfe's brother Albert; there is a third-party letter from Frida Kahlo to Leon Trotsky. Writings include corrected drafts of Wolfe's best-known novels, the science-fiction work Limbo (1952) and The Great Prince Died (1959), which was based on Trotsky's assassination. Other works include an "Outline for a Study of the Role of the Negro in American Popular Culture," essays on Connecticut labor in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and short fiction, some of which was published in Playboy in the 1960s. There are photographs, circa 1937, of Wolfe, Trotsky, Trotsky's wife Natalia Sedova, Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, Max Shachtman, and others. Printed materials include research material relating to Thomas Mann, clippings, and ephemera.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some materials in French and German.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Bernard Wolfe, 1959 and Albert Wolfe, 1990-2003.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 6 and 8 (videocassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Bernard Wolfe Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bernard Wolfe Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below according to month and year of acquisition.

The finding aid for this collection is compiled from individual preliminary lists for each acquisition that were created at or around the time of receipt by the library. The preliminary lists were migrated to comply with current archival descriptive standards and merged into a single file in 2007-2008. As part of the migration, modifications were made to the formatting of individual lists; however, the content of the lists was neither modified nor verified.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing. In February 2014, additional work was done on the collection to standardize the housing and description across acquisitions.

Former call numbers: Uncat Za Wolfe, Uncat Za Ms 133, Uncat Za Ms 187, Uncat Za Ms 229, Uncat Za Ms 263, Uncat Za File 293, Uncat Za Ms 313, Uncat Za Ms 411, Uncat Za Ms 543, Uncat Za Ms 555, Uncat Za Ms 569, Uncat Za Ms 606, and Uncat Za Ms 441.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings received as part of the April 1992 Acquisition were transferred to Historical Sound Recordings, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Bernard Wolfe (1915-1985)
bioghist.p: Bernard Wolfe, editor and author, was born in New Haven, Connecticut, on 28 August 1915 to Robert and Ida Gordon Wolfe. Wolfe was educated at Yale University (1935), where he was also a graduate student in 1935 and 1936, before he moved to Mexico to work as a secretary and translator for Leon Trotsky in 1937. Wolfe began his writing career as a freelance writer of novels and short stories and later worked as a screenwriter for Universal International Pictures, Tony Curtis Productions, and other film producers. During his writing career, Wolfe wrote in several genres, including biography, screenplays, pornography, and science fiction. For a time, he worked as a editor at Mechanix Illustrated magazine. His best-known novel, The Great Prince Died , which is based on Trostsky's assassination, was published in 1959. Wolfe's other notable work was a science-fiction novel, Limbo , published by Random House in 1952.
Biographical information taken from Guide to Literary Masters & Their Works , January 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, writings and research material, photographs, printed material, and personal papers relating to American author Bernard Wolfe. There is correspondence, including incoming and outgoing letters, with family, friends, writers, publishers, editors, and labor organizations. Individual corrrespondents include: Pearl Buck, Marcel Duhamel, Dwight MacDonald, Henry Miller, A. J. Muste, John Crowe Ranson, Harry Ross, and Wolfe's brother Albert; there is a third-party letter from Frida Kahlo to Leon Trotsky. Writings include corrected drafts of Wolfe's best-known novels, the science-fiction work, Limbo (1952), and The Great Prince Died (1959), which was based on Trotsky's assassination. Other works include an "Outline for a Study of the Role of the Negro in American Popular Culture," essays on Connecticut labor in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and short fiction, some of which was published in Playboy in the 1960s. There are photographs, circa 1937, of Wolfe, Trotsky, Trotsky's wife Natalia Sedova, Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, Max Shachtman, and others. Printed materials include research material relating to Thomas Mann, clippings, and ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into thirteen groupings: I. May 1959 Acquisition. II. April 1990 Acquisition. III. May 1991 Acquisition. IV. April 1992 Acquisition. V. September 1992 Acquisition. VI. February 1993 Acquisition. VII. December 1993 Acquisition. VIII. September 1994 Acquisition. IX. December 1997 Acquisition. X. March 1998 Acquisition. XI. September 1998 Acquisition. XII. January 1999 Acquisition. XIII. January 2003 Acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The May 1959 Acquisition contains a typescript draft, corrected, of Wolfe's novel about the murder of Leon Trostsky, The Great Prince Died (1959).
Former call number: Uncat Za Wolfe.

did.unittitle: The Great Prince Died , draft, typescript, corrected

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The April 1990 Acquisition contains two drafts of Wolfe's novel Limbo , one "First Draft," typescript and autograph manuscript, heavily corrected and annotated, accompanied by a typed letter signed from Wolfe to Don Congdon dating from 1951, and a later, undated typescript carbon draft.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 133.

did.unittitle: Limbo , draft, typescript and autograph manuscript, corrected

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The May 1991 Acquisition contains a draft of the "Outline for a Study of the Role of the Negro in American Popular Culture," a photograph album, and a printed guide to the Max Shachtman Collection at the Tamiment Institute/Ben Josephson Library. The photograph album contains black-and-white photographs, circa 1930s, of Wolfe, Leon Trotsky, Natalia Sedova, Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, and others.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 187.

did.unittitle: "Outline for a Study of the Role of the Negro in American Popular Culture," draft, typescript and typescript carbon
New York University Bulletin of the Tamiment Institute/Ben Josephson Library

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings transferred to Historical Sound Recordings, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The April 1992 Acquisition consists of correspondence, writings, and other papers dating largely from the mid to late 1930s. There is correspondence between Bernard Wolfe and his brother Albert, Max Fleischman, Harry Ross, and others, including a third-party letter from Frida Kahlo to Leon Trotsky, and writings by Wolfe, Trotsky, and others. Writings by Trotsky appear to consist chiefly of copies and translations of short works made by Wolfe in his capacity as secretary and translator to Trotsky in 1937, while Trotsky lived in exile in Mexico.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 229.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 6 (videocassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The September 1992 Acquisition includes correspondence, financial records, photographs, printed material, and videocassettes relating to Wolfe and/or Trotsky.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 263.

did.unittitle: Bill submitted to Standard Oil Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes nine typed letters, signed from Wolfe to his mother and one typed letter, signed to Wolfe from Hopewell Rogers

did.unittitle: "Leon Trotsky en Mexico City (Coyoqcah): Filmado por Alex Buchman, entre Noviembre 1939 y Abril 1940"
"'Trotsky' - A Two-Part, Two-Hour Telefilm by Ima of Paris"
did.materialspec: Video levels vary throughtout the program.

did.unittitle: "'Trotsky's Home Movies", A British Channel 4 Production
did.materialspec: Video levels vary througout the program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Broadcast on the 50th anniversary of LDT's assassination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The February 1993 Acquisition consists of four photographs: two photographs of Leon Trotsky, inscribed by Trotsky to Wolfe; one photograph of Trotsky and Diego Rivera, also inscribed by Trotsky to Wolfe; and one photograph including Trotsky, Natalia Sedova, Frida Kahlo, and Max Shachtman.
Former call number: Uncat Za File 293.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The December 1993 Acquisition consists of nine color photographs of Leon Trotsky, three with Natalia Sedova, by A. H. Buchman, as well as a manuscript by Richard Wright, inscribed by Bernard Wolfe.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 313.

did.unittitle: "A Hitherto Unpublished Manuscript by Richard Wright Being a Continuation of Black Boy..." printed version

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The September 1994 Acquisition contains correspondence and printed material. There are letters between Bernard Wolfe and his brother Albert, Warren C. Montross, A. J. Muste, and others. Printed materials include a version of the a story "Self Portrait".
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 411.

did.unittitle: "Self Portrait," story, printed version, Galaxy: Science Fiction

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 8 (videocassette): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The December 1997 Acquisition consists of a single videocassette containing a Spanish documentary, entitled "Asaltar Los Cielos (Assault the Heavens)," on Ramon Mercader, the man who assassinated Leon Trotsky in Mexico in 1940.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 543.

did.materialspec: There is a high amount of hiss on the tape.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a Spanish documentary on Ramon Mercader, the assassin of Trotsky. Substitles are in English. It runs approximately 1 1/2 hours.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The March 1998 Acquisition consists chiefly of unsorted correspondence, including incoming and outgoing letters with family, friends, writers, publishers, editors, and labor organizations. Corrrespondents include: Pearl [Buck?], Marcel Duhamel, Dwight MacDonald, Henry Miller, John Crowe Ranson, and others. Also includes biographical material.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 555.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The September 1998 Acquisition contains photocopies and printed versions of short writings by Wolfe and others, including short stories, articles, and interviews. Stories includes: "The Never Ending Penny," "Come On Out, Daddy," and other works. The dates listed below are publication dates.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 569.
